node.title: Amazon agrees to pay $500,000 in California over claims that it hid Covid-19 cases from workers.
node.alt: Rob Bonta, California’s attorney general, speaking outside an Amazon building in San Francisco last week. “No corporation is too big to follow the law,” he said on Monday.
node.description: The judgment, which is subject to court approval, is in line with a “right to know” law that was designed to keep workers safe in the pandemic.
node.content: ["Amazon has agreed to pay $500,000 to help enforce California\u2019s consumer protection laws after the company was accused of concealing Covid-19 case numbers from its workers, officials said on Monday.", "The judgment, which is subject to court approval, is the first of its kind nationwide and is in line with a California \u201cright to know\u201d law that was designed to keep workers safe during the pandemic, according to a news release from the attorney general\u2019s office.", "Under the arrangement, Amazon must also tell its warehouse workers within a day about the exact number of new Covid-19 cases in their workplaces, ensure that notifications adequately inform workers of the company\u2019s disinfection and safety plans, tell health officials about new cases and submit to monitoring by the attorney general\u2019s office regarding its Covid-19 notifications.", "Amazon did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Tuesday.", "A complaint filed in Superior Court in Sacramento maintained that Amazon\u2019s actions had prevented employees and the public from gaining full access to information regarding Covid-19 cases.", "The state\u2019s attorney general, Rob Bonta, said that such information was crucial for workers making difficult decisions regarding their health in the pandemic.", "\u201cAmazon\u2019s practices led to workers not knowing if they had been potentially exposed to two, 20 or even 200 cases of Covid-19,\u201d he said at a news conference on Monday. \u201cThis left many workers understandably terrified and powerless to make informed decisions to protect themselves and to protect their loved ones.\u201d", "\u201cNo corporation is too big to follow the law,\u201d Mr. Bonta said. \u201cThis is a huge win for the safety and health of Amazon\u2019s tens of thousands of warehouse workers, their families and our communities throughout this state.\u201d", "He said that the judgment sent a clear message that businesses must comply with the law, and that it was particularly important as the busy holiday season approached."]
